member.name: T:OAuth2Client.AuthHandler.OAuth2BearerHandler
member.summary:
This Handler can be supplied to System.Net.HttpClient to pemit it to work against an OAuth2-protected host. It will add the appropriate Authorization header to requests, and will refresh the OAuth2 access token if the request fails due to a 401.
The storage will be used to gather the secrets and credentials, and will be used to store the credentials if they end up being refreshed.

member.name: M:OAuth2Client.AuthHandler.shouldRefresh(System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage)
member.summary: We should only refresh if we see the OAuth2 WWW-Authenticate in the 401.

member.name: M:OAuth2Client.AuthHandler.collectBearerParams(System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage)
member.summary: Find any "WWW-Authenticate: Bearer" headers in the response.

member.name: M:OAuth2Client.AuthHandler.parseParams(System.String)
member.summary:
Attempt to parse the "x=y, z=q" style parameters from a WWW-Authenticate header In a 401 from an OAuth2 endpoint, WWW-Authenticate might look like this:
WWW-Authenticate: Bearer realm="example", error="invalid_token", error_description="The access token expired"
See http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6750#page-7

member.name: M:OAuth2Client.Extensions.HttpClient.HttpClient.WithOAuth2.Static(OAuth2Client.IStorageAsync,System.String,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpOption{System.Net.Http.HttpClientHandler})
member.summary: Create a new HttpClient with the Oauth2 auth handler already plugged in. The storage will be used to gather the existing secrets and credentials, and to store any newly refreshed credentials from the OAuth2 host. If no inner handler is specified, a new System.Net.Http.HttpClientHandler will be created to handle requests.
